channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: FBI searches home of Washington Post reporter as part of leak investigation
item.description: The FBI searched the home of a Washington Post reporter who covers the federal government, seizing her laptops, phone and smart watch. The move has alarmed free speech advocates and the media.
item.content:encoded: The FBI searched the home of a Washington Post reporter who covers the federal government, seizing her laptops, phone and smart watch. The move has alarmed free speech advocates and the media.
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: First Amendment lawyer says FBI's search of journalist's home is 'radical escalation'
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin asks First Amendment lawyer Theodore Boutrous about the FBI executing a search warrant at the home of a Washington Post reporter.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Michel Martin asks First Amendment lawyer Theodore Boutrous about the FBI executing a search warrant at the home of a Washington Post reporter.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: 2025 was among the hottest years on record, continuing a concerning trend
item.description: Federal scientists have found that 2025 was among the hottest years on record since the Industrial Revolution, continuing a warming trend and bringing Earth closer to a crucial threshold.
item.content:encoded: Federal scientists have found that 2025 was among the hottest years on record since the Industrial Revolution, continuing a warming trend and bringing Earth closer to a crucial threshold.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sommer

item.title: Uganda goes to the polls amid heavy security and internet blackout
item.description: Ugandans are voting in a tense presidential election as 81-year-old President Yoweri Museveni seeks to extend his four-decade rule amid an internet shutdown and heavy military deployment.
item.content:encoded:
Ugandans are voting in a tense presidential election as 81-year-old President Yoweri Museveni seeks to extend his four-decade rule amid an internet shutdown and heavy military deployment.

(Image credit: Ben Curtis)
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: More students are going to college. Affordability and workforce training are factors
item.description: Overall enrollment is up slightly at colleges and universities, driven by gains at community colleges and public four-year programs.
item.content:encoded: Overall enrollment is up slightly at colleges and universities, driven by gains at community colleges and public four-year programs.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: 'I want to make tiny little movies that don't seem tiny,' says Kristen Stewart
item.description: In her feature-length directorial debut, actor Kristen Stewart adapts The Chronology of Water, the memoir of Lidia Yuknavitch, a competitive swimmer-turned-author who was abused as a child.
item.content:encoded:
In her feature-length directorial debut, actor Kristen Stewart adapts The Chronology of Water, the memoir of Lidia Yuknavitch, a competitive swimmer-turned-author who was abused as a child.

(Image credit: Emily Soto)
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The FBI searched a Washington Post reporter's home Wednesday, Denmark says a working group will be formed to address U.S. concerns, Trump administration reverses mental health cuts.
item.content:encoded: The FBI searched a Washington Post reporter's home Wednesday, Denmark says a working group will be formed to address U.S. concerns, Trump administration reverses mental health cuts.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: Tensions remain high Minneapolis as anti-ICE protests continue
item.description: Tensions are high in the Twin Cities over ICE's crackdown. A state lawsuit calls the agency's tactics dangerous and unconstitutional while Trump officials say that protestors are the real problem.
item.content:encoded: Tensions are high in the Twin Cities over ICE's crackdown. A state lawsuit calls the agency's tactics dangerous and unconstitutional while Trump officials say that protestors are the real problem.
item.dc:creator: Martin Kaste

item.title: What to do if you encounter law enforcement: Your rights explained
item.description: What rights do U.S. citizens and non-citizens have when they encounter law enforcement? NPR's A Martinez speaks with Georgetown University law professor Paul Butler.
item.content:encoded: What rights do U.S. citizens and non-citizens have when they encounter law enforcement? NPR's A Martinez speaks with Georgetown University law professor Paul Butler.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: Denmark and U.S. to form working group to talk about U.S. security concerns
item.description: After meeting with President Trump's top aides, Danish officials say they will form a working group to talk through U.S. security concerns about control of Greenland.
item.content:encoded: After meeting with President Trump's top aides, Danish officials say they will form a working group to talk through U.S. security concerns about control of Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez
